posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked:
Let’s say that the inverse kinematics tells module one to go to 0 degrees and the speed is 0.5 and module one can choose to do that directly, so it will drive the machine straight forward at half a speed.  But we know that the output of the motor controller can be any number between -1 and 1.  Module 1 can also choose to turn to 180 degrees and output -0.5 to achieve the same effect.  So how should we judge?  So what you need to do is you need to read what Angle it’s at, make a judgment based on whether the actual Angle is closer to 180 degrees or closer to 0 degrees, and decide whether you want to reverse the output.

So does WPI merge this part in the official swerve code ?

And also another question about continuous rotation.

In a normal PID controller, 0 and 360 are obviously not the same thing.  But this is a tricky problem in vector modules, because 0 degrees, 360 degrees, 720 degrees and so on are really the same position on the circumference of the circle.  If not handled properly in the program, the module will rotate more than 180 degrees in order to reach the target, greatly decreasing efficiency.

Therefore, the module control program to adjust the control target, feed to the PID controller.  For example, now the module sensor is displayed at 720 degrees, and the inverse kinematics calculation requires the module to turn to 0 degrees, then the input to the PID should be 720 degrees (it does not need to turn at all, nor will it turn).  But if you put zero directly into the PID as a target, it will foolishly rotate twice to return to the same position.

So has WPI already put this part in the example swerve code , or l need to write it myself?

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
mendax1234:

So what you need to do is you need to read what Angle it’s at, make a judgment based on whether the actual Angle is closer to 180 degrees or closer to 0 degrees, and decide whether you want to reverse the output.

SwerveModuleState.optimize() was made for this purpose.

mendax1234:

Therefore, the module control program to adjust the control target, feed to the PID controller. For example, now the module sensor is displayed at 720 degrees, and the inverse kinematics calculation requires the module to turn to 0 degrees, then the input to the PID should be 720 degrees (it does not need to turn at all, nor will it turn). But if you put zero directly into the PID as a target, it will foolishly rotate twice to return to the same position.

If you enable “continous input” mode in PIDController or ProfiledPIDController, it’ll do what you want.

Both of the swerve example projects (SwerveBot and SwerveControllerCommand) demonstrate these features.

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked: Ok and thanks. I wonder which part l need to adjust according to my own robot if l use the Example Swerve code.

posts.name: Nolan
posts.cooked:

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked:
Hello, it seems that WPILIB’s swerve code wasn’t completed by one person. For example, in the SwerveBot , the setSesiredState was below:

However , in the SwerveControllerCommand , the setDesiredState function is below:

Although this seems to be unnecessary , but maybe the SwerveBot’s setDesiredState() is the optimization of the SwerveControllerCommand , and if a newly bird see this example , maybe he will be very puzzled . He may wonder which one l would use, which is better . Just like me , l am also very puzzled. What’s more , there is also a difference in these two examples .

In the SwerveBot’s Robot.java the method to get x and y values from the XboxController is different from that in the SwerveControllerCommand. Not only is the method different , but also the position of what it will be used is different. l think maybe this is a bug. The relative code of SwerveBot:

The relative SwerveControllerCommand code is below:

From the code above , my questions are below : What’s the use of slawratelimiter , or maybe it is not so necessary that that WPI doesn’t use it in another Swerve Example. Besides, just like the bug l have mentioned above ,the drivecommmand in the RobotContainer.java of SwerveControllerCommand example is partly wrong , from my perspective. Or the SwerveBot’s drivecommmanad is wrong. Because in the swervecontrollercommand , they use the LeftY and RightX to controll the forward and strafe speed of a Swerve Module , and Left to controll the rotation speed. However , in the SwerveBot Example , it is clear that we use LeftY and LeftX to controll the forward and strafe speed and RightX to controll the rotation speed. And in my opinion, the second method is more reasonable from my practice . l report this issue because l am very puzzled when l study the Swerve example code . And l will be very thankful if anybody can help me with it!

l have started a new topic to let more people to see it ,

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
mendax1234:

What’s the use of slawratelimiter

Check here if you haven’t yet: Slew Rate Limiter — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation .

mendax1234:

l have mentioned above ,the drivecommmand in the RobotContainer.java of SwerveControllerCommand example is partly wrong , from my perspective.

It could be, though I’m not entirely clear on what you’re indicating is actually the bug.

In general, there is not a single solution for the mapping of joystick axes to buttons to commands - so I’d not be concerned if there are some differences there.

m_robotDrive.drive() and m_swerve.drive() do very similar things, but aren’t the same method. Therefor, I’d be digging deeper than the initial call to determine if differences really matter.

What I do see that seems concerning - in the non-command-based example , joystick values (range [-1.0, 1.0]) are used when creating a ChassisSpeed object. However, ChassisSpeed should be taking in real-world units values of the speed in meters-per-second (range ~[-4.0, 4.0] or so, depends on the robot).

I have not run or debug either example to confirm it’s actually an issue though.

link_counts.title: Slew Rate Limiter — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked: Thanks l doesn’t mean that it is a bug , but l mean that it is not friendly to rookies since we doesn’t know which is the better way to control a swerve drive because they have given two methods. Something are included in one method , while some are not. This may let people suspect (like me) whether this solution is effective , why we use it instead of using the direct one. Getting values from Joystick is an example , the two example code has two methods to get it . One gets it directly and one gets through SlawRateLimiter, maybe the latter wants to optimize the input. But if l only see the former example , l won’t know this. In a nutshell , it is from some aspects not so friendly to rookies.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
The thought I’d share on the topic: Swerve itself is not rookie-friendly - especially not compared to differential drive configurations.

Both drivetrains serve the same purpose: move the robot from Point A to Point B. However, swerve drive will have 4x the degrees of freedom of a differential drive (8 motor control groups, rather than 2).

Since there are more degrees of freedom, there are more options on how to constrain them. Some are clearly better than others. But, for many, the answer is “it depends”.

As an engineer, your job is to dig deeply into each of those “it depends” cases to determine a concrete answer, sufficient to accomplish your robot’s objectives. The Scientific Method is an excellent template for how to do this.

For example, using SlewRateLimiter , here’s how I’d approach it:

Observation/Question: Does your swerve code implementation require a SlewRateLimiter on joystick commands?

Research: a) One functional example applies SlewRateLimiter to driver joystick commands, while the other does not. b) Documentation on what a slew rate limiter does. c) Opinions and requirements from the robot drivers on whether they would desire the behavior SlewRateLimiter causes. d) Ask targeted questions to experts.

Hypothesis: Pick an implementation that best aligns with the goals you know about on your team

Test/Experiment: Write code which tests the hypothesis, and run it.

Analyze Data: Get one or more people to interact with the code’s behavior. Determine whether the code’s behavior matches your intent.

Report Conclusions: Choose whether your implementation is good enough, or if you need to try something else. GOTO step 1 as needed.

Note this is the long format: In practice, a lot of these steps happen very quickly, even simultaneously, perhaps in your brain alone. That’s why I like to call engineering “the real-time application of the scientific method”. Still - to be successful, you can’t skip the important steps. You’ll learn with time which steps are compressable/skippable. But, when starting, be pedantic and methodical while solving problems like this.

And, of note, particularly for 2d. In my experience, 90% of the time, the experts don’t give me the answer: They give me the question .

Experts show me the things I forgot or didn’t consider, or the constraints I still need to define. From there, I myself take their new questions back and answer them. From there, the solution falls out in a trivial manner.

link_counts.title: Slew Rate Limiter — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked: Much thanks!

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked: Hello , l have a question . That’s we use PID in the swerve drive. Does it means that our robot weren’t be pushed by other robots when we drive . Because our inputs are same , and the code use encoders , so if other robots can’t bump into us to let us move . Is that right?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
I suspect you’ve got the underlying idea correct. What you refer to is called disturbance rejection in the academic circles.

Closed loop control will try to achieve some target state (wheel speed in this case). When some external disturbance (aka, contact with another robot) occurs, the controller will fight back against it to the best of its ability.

There are of course limits: If the external force is greater than the force the motors can exert on the ground to hold your robot in place, your robot will move. But that’s beyond the point where software could help.

Here’s a very very old demo of disturbance rejection on a strange drivetrain we built many years ago. . A gyroscope is used to keep the robot pointed in the same direction. When kicked, the drivetrain does it’s best to fight against the push and return to the original position.

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked: Thanks， but will the motor give the robot which disturbs it an equal and reverse force to stay in its original place?

posts.name: Nolan
posts.cooked: There is latency to measure/command motors and control efforts will never be perfect, so it will not stay in exactly the same place. Depending on your implementation you might have a more or less aggressive response to the disturbance while it is applied and thus more or less deviation from your original position. Either way, once the disturbance ends the robot should return to the original position.

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked: It will return to the original place automatically?

posts.name: Nolan
posts.cooked: Sorry, I assumed this was autonomous-- If you are tracking a trajectory with swerve it would act like this(PID on x,y,theta). Generally teleop driver control would be velocity commands, so the robot would only resist external forces(but would still drift). If you wanted to have this with driver control you would have to command a desired robot pose instead of desired robot velocity.

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked: So , when the robot was in teleoperated period , when other robots bump it , will it still stay in the original place? For example , when we try to aim at the target and during this period of time , other robots may disturb us .

posts.name: Nolan
posts.cooked: As I said, it depends on how you control the robot. If you are just driving in teleop normally it will push against other robots but will still be moved. Depending on your vision alignment strategy, the robot will readjust to the goal after being pushed(you probably won’t be able to shoot while you are being pushed very well).
